Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Development of a Machine Learning Platform to Predict Surgical Complications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to create a personalized, precision-based practice paradigm for surgery that improves surgical outcomes and reduces the cost of healthcare. This paradigm utilizes individual patient characteristics with machine-learning algorithms to accurately predict the risk of post-surgical complications. Additionally, it offers the possibility of enacting impactful interventions among high-risk patients, while reducing unnecessary therapies among low-risk patients, thereby improving surgical outcomes, maximizing the efficiency of healthcare, and minimizing cost. In a value-based care model, this paradigm aligns the goals of health systems, surgeons, and patients.

The proposed project combines individual patient data with machine-learning algorithms to effectively predict surgical complication risk and improve surgical clinical outcomes. Currently, 13% of 50 million surgical procedures performed in the United States annually result in a surgical complication, half which are potentially avoidable. A primary cause of avoidable complications include significant variable in risk assessment and standardized preventative practice. Therefore, the principal objective of this proposal is to develop machine-learning predictive models of various surgical complications (wound, cardiac, respiratory, renal, etc.), which provides an objective risk assessment for surgeons. Additionally, this risk assessment platform will allow stratification of patients into high- vs. low-risk categories and link patients with risk-appropriate preventative interventions at the point-of-care.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This STTR Phase I proposal targeted the problem of surgical complications, which occurs in 13% of 50 million surgical procedures performed in the United States annually. Surgical complications are costly, averaging $11,626 per event, but half are potentially avoidable (Dimick et al. 2004). This represents an estimated $38 billion spent by the U.S. healthcare system on avoidable complications, without consideration of the economic costs associated with loss of productivity, social sequelae associated with loss of function, etc. Currently, perioperative management relies on subjective surgeon experience and current?and often incomplete?knowledge of ever-changing best-practice recommendations, resulting in significant variability in risk assessment and preventative practice. Therefore, the principal objective of this proposal was to develop and test a software platform that links accurate and objective risk stratification with evidence-based interventions targeting specific complications for surgical providers at the point of care.

KelaHealth implements a personalized, risk-based approach for conducting preventative perioperative surgical care with future applicability to a broad range of surgical and medical specialties. This approach differs from other purely predictive tools in that it combines machine learning-based risk stratification with evidence-based interventions in order to tailor recommendations to high risk patients at the point of care.  It offers the potential to prevent complications by concentrating more aggressive preventative care on patients with the greater risk profiles, thereby improving patients? quality of life while reducing unnecessary hospital stays and overall healthcare costs. This technology functions as applied big data analytics in the modern healthcare system which seeks to disseminate quality improvement within an increasingly value-based care model.


Our solution is made possible by our interdisciplinary team made up of 1) clinicians who care for surgical patients day-to-day, 2) data scientists who have pushed the boundaries of diverse fields such as telecommunications, genomics, and medical imaging, and 3) software engineers experienced in architecting enterprise solutions with high throughput for millions of customers. Because of this unique mix of expertise, our team knows how to rigorously leverage data and software technologies to deliver actionable insights within the right workflow, at the right time, to influence clinical decisions that impact patient outcomes.


During the period of this grant, we showed that the KelaHealth?s platform can house predictive models that can be applied on real-world EHR clinical datasets to generate complication risks for patients. This stratification of the surgical population into high vs. low risk patients is most useful when applied directly to next step actions that can guide clinicians and hospitals to deploy targeted interventions for better resource allocation, clinical outcomes and cost savings. We proved this in two surgical use cases during the period of this grant in cardiac and vascular surgeries, demonstrating potential for impacting clinical outcomes such as reducing surgical site infections (up to 41%) and reducing the cost of care (up to 50%). The translation of these results means patients can have better, safer outcomes from their medical procedures and hospitals can provide quality care while saving millions of dollars per year.


Ultimately, KelaHealth's paradigm helps health systems to efficiently deploy its resources and optimize patient outcomes, while saving overall cost of care. By showing the impact of using our prediction platform in practical applications, we have proven that health systems are willing to engage with us as early partners in improving healthcare.


Last Modified: 01/31/2019
Modified by: Bora Chang
